body:
Further investigation.

I installed IONinja and sniffed the named pipes being used between ruby and powershell

## Working test

In this case I used the `-Version 2.0` flag to the initial powershell call

Note that `File #12` is the outbound pipe from ruby into powershell STDIN and `File #11` is in the inbound pipe into Powershell STDIN from ruby.  See that the content from `File #12` equals the content to `File #11`.

They appear out of order in the log because the timestamps are the same

You can see the inverse behaviour in `File #14` and `File #13` which his STDOUT pipe from powershell to ruby.  These are it the correct oder as you can see by the timestamps

## Failing Test

This time I used the powershell command without a version specifier i.e. PS 5.1
Log file

```

                    < 0010  31 22 0a 57 72 69 74 65 2d 4f 75 74 70 75 74 20  1".Write-Output 
                    < 0020  22 32 22 0a 57 72 69 74 65 2d 4f 75 74 70 75 74  "2".Write-Output
```

Note that `File #4` is the outbound pipe from ruby into powershell STDIN and `File #3` is in the inbound pipe into Powershell STDIN from ruby.

See that the data is put into the pipe but it never gets read out at the powershell pipe end.  This suggests there's something up with the pipe handling.

I updated the repro making it slightly simpler (cloning puppetlabs-powershell wasn't necessary, just needed to add `require 'timeout'` to the script and it runs just fine with just `ruby` installed.

When I run the modified repro, it does hang when running the in-box `powershell.exe`, but exits correctly with my fix to #2090.

That said, the output is still missing. I verified that PowerShell is receiving the command and executing them, but the ruby script stopped reading from `stdout` before the commands ran. I increased the timeout and verified the output was received.

So I think this issue is the same as #2090, but it would be great if you can confirm.
